instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6258: What is ISL6258? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2008 through 2009.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message:
I have a liquid spilled <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> retina that had a minor liquid spill near the battery connector (customer used 50% alcohol to remove battery). No LED. Some spill was on <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP> area so I replaced that one and some small IC around it. Now the macbook can start up and working, it shows battery is charging in the top bar, however if I look in the system report - power it shows no charge, battery is going down. I have checked <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5381</RESISTOR> they seem OK (2K Ohm). Any other suggestions? 

PS also tried another battery same story

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message:
I guess you mean <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> not 58.............

Check sense resistors <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52, <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 and traces.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message: Yes sorry typo, thanks for the quick reply much appreciated, will test now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> = 0
<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> = 2.2 (not sure how to read that 2 2 in schematics... I guess 2.2?)
<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> = 10
<RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> = 10

Lines OK from pin 1 <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR>/51 to ISL and from pin 2 to <RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message: Does this machine power on without the battery connected? What voltage is PPBUS without battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message: No it doesnt, good one :), its 1.8v fluctuating a bit. Do have orange light on Charger. Looking for a short in AC charger circuit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message: Must be issue with sense resistors or some other component around <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>. Measure resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message:
So i did recheck:

1. Al lines from <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> to <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> are OK
2. Resistors have the right ohm
3. Pin 17 resistance to ground = 0.694
    Pin 18 = 0.617
    Pin 27 = 0.592
    Pin 28 = 0.597

Or I have to measure resistance between pins differently? Sorry im a bit of a noob. I only know red probe on ground black on measure point which is what i did:). Could it also be a bad ISL IC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge the battery
threads.message: I asked the resistance between 17/18 and 27/28 not diode mode to GND. I can already tell there is something wrong with 17/18 as on diode mode they should be almost the same. Check traces going to 17/18
